Poly(amidoamine) dendrimer immobilized on mesoporous silica foam (MSF) and fibrous nano-silica KCC-1 for Gd3+ adsorption in water
Yu-Ri Leea,b, Siqian Zhanga, Kwangsun Yua, Jinsub Choia, Wha-Seung Ahna,⁎
a Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inha University, Incheon 402-751, Republic of Korea bMaterials Architecturing Research Center, Korea Institute of Science and Technology, Seoul 02792, Republic of Korea
H I G H L I G H T S
• Poly(amidoamine) dendrimer was grafted on mesoporous silica foam and fibrous silica KCC-1. • The prepared adsorbents were extensively characterized after each preparation step. • Gd3+ adsorption over the adsorbents was examined under various experimental conditions. • Mesoporous silica foam was more effective as a host than KCC-1 for the dendrimer. • High adsorption capacity and recyclability with good selectivity were confirmed.
G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
High performance adsorption of Gd3+ by the second generation poly(amidoamine) dendrimer immobilized on mesoporous silica foam (MSF) and fibrous nano-silica KCC-1.
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Rare earth elements Mesoporous silica foam KCC-1 Dendrimer Adsorption equilibrium and kinetics Structural stability
A B S T R A C T
Separation and recovery of low concentration rare earth elements (REEs) from aqueous environment need to be considered to meet their growing demand for high-technology devices. In this work, the second-generation poly (amidoamine) dendrimers immobilized on a mesoporous silica foam (MSF) or a fibrous nano-silica KCC-1 (PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1, respectively) were prepared after systematic grafting of 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane and glutaraldehyde (GTA) as a cross-linking spacer. These were investigated for recovery of gadolinium ions (Gd3+) in water via adsorption. The prepared adsorbents were extensively characterized in each preparation step by various analytical instruments, and successful attachment of the organic groups on the silica supports was confirmed. The Gd3+ adsorption over the functionalized materials was examined under different conditions of the solution pH, initial Gd3+ concentrations, and adsorption time. PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF performed better than PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1, with exceptionally high adsorption capacity (ca. 132mg/g) and recyclability with reasonable selectivity for potential commercial use. Gd3+ selectivity against competing ions could be further enhanced to ca. 86% by successive functionalization with N(phosphonomethyl) iminodiacetic acid on PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF.

In addition, considering the relative toxicity associated with the accumulation of REEs towards living organisms [3], it has become increasingly necessary to conduct their separation and purification more efficient and economical.
The conventional techniques used industrially for separation of REEs are liquid–liquid extraction [4], electrochemical separation [5], ion-exchange [6], chemical precipitation [7], and adsorption [8]. Since many of them are costly and accompanied by high chemical and energy consumption [9,10], adsorption has been generally considered as a more environmentally benign and efficient option for recovery of REEs. Adsorption is especially suitable for low-concentration sources [10]. Adsorbents for REE recovery should possess adequate structural stability with desirable textural properties under acidic aqueous conditions to keep high adsorption capacity after regeneration of the adsorbents together with high selectivity towards REEs competing against the presence of alkali- or transition metal ions. Up to now, various types of adsorbents such as silica-based materials [11–15], metal oxides [16], carbon nanotubes [17], biomass [18,19], and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) [20–22] have been applied as adsorbents for REE recovery. Functionalized metal oxides are efficient for adsorption, but their recovery for reuse is often difficult because of the small particle size [16]. MOFs are mostly microporous and suffer potential diffusion limitation, and they also show inadequate stability during the regeneration processes [10,23]. By comparison, carbon materials are more stable, but allow only limited scope for surface functionalization with organic groups for effective adsorption of REEs [24]. Silica-based materials, on the other hand, possess abundant surface silanol groups (Si-OH) that enable efficient functionalization through condensation reactions with various organic species [25], and they are also stable commonly used for REE recovery (in the pH range of 3–8). Modified mesoporous silica adsorbents have been broadly applied for selective adsorption of heavy (including REEs) and radioactive metal ions [10,26,27].
Mesoporous silica foams (MSFs) are comprised of a large number of spherical cells interconnected in a three-dimensional pore system through uniform windows. Easily synthesized in acidic media [28], MSFs have been increasingly employed in both gas- and liquid-phase systems owing to their high surface area (> 500m2/g), large pore volume (1.4 cm3/g), and large pore size (average window diameter:
11 nm, average cell diameter: 29 nm). These structural features allow the incorporation of a large quantity of organic moieties into the porous network and easy diffusion of target ions into the matrix [29]. Recently, a unique material of fibrous silica nanospheres with high surface area, designated as KCC-1 [30], was also prepared through a reverse-micelle templating method and showed excellent performances in masstransfer-controlled processes [31]. The active sites for adsorption and catalysis positioned on the outside surface of the fibrous KCC-1 structure are expected to decrease the mass-transfer resistances. Both of these silica materials can be promising host materials for REE recovery. However, only limited studies have been reported so far [32,33].
Effectiveness of adsorbent materials is primarily governed by their specific surface properties and the functional groups responsible for adsorption, and the selection of suitable functional chelating groups is vital to achieving high adsorption efficiency and selectivity. Since REE ions are Lewis acids, Lewis base ligands containing oxygen, amides, carbonyl groups, and nitrogen species have often been employed as chelators for REEs recovery [10,34]. In this regard, poly(amidoamine) (PAMAM) dendrimer in its well-defined three-dimensional hyperbranched structure with a high population of amine and amide species in highly developed cavities (Fig. S1) [35] can be useful as an active functional group for the recovery of REEs. Owing to the advantages of significant cationic charge density and a branched network, PAMAM has been applied for the removal of heavy metal ions [36–39]. Zhao and coworkers prepared a dendrimer-grafted cellulose nanofibril aerogel for the isolation of Cr(VI) in aqueous solutions [36], reporting the adsorption capacity of 377mg/g. Qu et al. reported the synthesis of silica gel supported salicylaldehyde modified PAMAM dendrimers for removal of Hg(II) [37] and silica-gel supported hyperbranched PAMAM dendrimers for the removal of Pb(II) [38]. Recently, Shi et al. also reported the synthesis of an electrospun cellulose acetate nanofiber modified with dendrimers for medical use [39].
In this work, the second-generation G2 PAMAM dendrimer was immobilized on MSF and KCC-1 (PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1, respectively) using glutaraldehyde (GTA) as a cross-linking spacer at the surface grafted with 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (Scheme 1), and the products were tested as adsorbents for the recovery of Gd3+ in aqueous solutions. Despite the promising properties of the dendrimer as a chelating ligand and mesoporous silicas as a rigid support for adsorption, dendrimer functionalized

mesoporous silicas with different pore structures such as MSF or KCC-1 has not been reported so far for REEs adsorption. In order to verify the actual binding sites for REE ions on the adsorbents, the chemical analysis and equilibrium adsorption measurements of the functionalized materials for Gd3+ were made after each functionalization step.
The adsorption behaviors were studied in detail under varying conditions of initial Gd3+ concentration, solution pH, and adsorption time. The effect of textural properties of the different silica support materials used on the adsorption process was examined principally through Gd3+ adsorption: equilibrium adsorption values attained and the time taken to reach the equilibrium states. The selective adsorption of Gd3+ in the presence of other potentially competing cation species as well as the reusability of the adsorbents was examined. Finally, the post-synthetic introduction of an extra organic group to the PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF was considered to improve the Gd3+ selectivity.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals and reagents
sections.text: Acetic acid, ammonium fluoride, sodium silicate, 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene (TMB), tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS), cetylpyridinium bromide, Pluronic P123 (EO/20:PO/70:EO/20), n-butanol, cyclohexane, 1-pentane, ethanol, methanol, toluene, acetic acid, glutaraldehyde (GTA, 5% aq.), sodium cyanoborohydride, 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES), PAMAM dendrimer (ethylenediamine core, generation 2.0 solution, 20 wt% in methanol), N-(phosphonomethyl) iminodiacetic acid (PMIDA, 95%), N,N’-dicyclohexylcarbodiimide (DCC, 99%), La(NO3)3·6H2O (99.9%), Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (99.9%), Nd (NO3)3·6H2O (99.9%), and Gd(NO3)3·6H2O (99.9%), Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (99.9%), Al(NO3) 3·9H2O (99.9%), Ca(NO3)2·4H2O, Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (99.9%), and NaCl (99.9%) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich, and used as received.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of mesoporous silica MSF and KCC-1
sections.text: Mesoporous silica MSF and KCC-1 were synthesized according to the reported procedures [28,40], and the synthesis details with the chemicals used are given in Supporting Information, SI-1.

sections.heading: 2.3. Post-synthetic immobilization of G2 PAMAM dendrimer on MSF and KCC-1
sections.text: For the APTES functionalization of the prepared MSF, 1 g of the MSF was put into anhydrous toluene (100mL), and 5mmol of APTES was charged into the solution. The mixture was then refluxed for 12 h. After the reaction, the obtained product was filtered, washed with ethanol three times, and dried at 100 °C for 5 h in a vacuum oven. The resulting material was designated as NH2-MSF. Then, 1 g of the NH2-MSF was added to 500mL anhydrous methanol containing 5% GTA, and the mixture was stirred for 3 h at 25 °C. The resultant GTA-activated NH2MSF was washed three times with methanol and dried at 100 °C for 4 h to obtain solvent-free GTA-NH2-MSF. The GTA-NH2-MSF was dispersed in 200mL anhydrous methanol containing 1mL of G2 PAMAM dendrimer by ultrasonication, and the mixture was stirred for 3 h at room temperature. After washing with anhydrous methanol three times, 1% w/w sodium cyanoborohydride as reduction agent was added, followed by 2 h of reaction at room temperature to produce the dendrimerfunctionalized material (PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF). Finally, the PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF was filtered, washed with anhydrous methanol and ethanol several times each, and dried at 60 °C overnight. PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1was also prepared similarly.

sections.heading: 2.4. Post-synthetic grafting of PMIDA on PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF (PMIDA/PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF)
sections.text: The synthetic sequence for the PMIDA/PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF is shown in Fig. S2. Based on the amount of nitrogen in the PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF after activation at 100 °C for 12 h, a mixture of PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF:PMIDA:DCC in a molar ratio of 1:1.5:2 was charged into 80mL of DMF in a round-bottom flask. The mixture was refluxed at 150 °C for 48 h to obtain PMIDA/ PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF. The final product was recovered and washed with toluene and methanol successively, and dried at 100 °C for 12 h.

sections.heading: 2.5. Characterization of the synthesized materials
sections.text: The synthesized and further surface-functionalized materials were characterized by various instrumentation, and the details of the methods are given in the SI-2.

sections.heading: 2.6. REEs adsorption experiments
sections.text: The prepared materials were tested for adsorption equilibrium and its pH dependency, the adsorption kinetics, specific metal ion selectivity, and adsorbent reusability at 25 °C in a batch experimental unit. The detailed experimental procedures for these measurements are given in SI-3 to 6.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of the materials
sections.text:
Scheme 1 illustrates the synthesis procedures of PAMAM@GTANH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1. The mesoporous silica supports were initially functionalized with APTES, and then an aldehyde ligand, GTA, was bound to the terminal amine groups of APTES on the surface by an imine condensation reaction. Finally, G2 PAMAM dendrimer can be attached to the silica supports via the glutaraldehyde spacer in the presence of sodium cyanoborohydride as a reducing agent.
Fig. 1 and Table 1 show the N2 adsorption isotherms, pore size distribution, and the textural properties of the prepared adsorbents. As shown in Fig. 1 (a) and (c), type IV isotherms with H1 or H3 hysteresis loops were detected for both materials, which are in line with the characteristics of the cylindrical mesopores [41]. Compared with the pristine silica materials of MSF and KCC-1, the organic group-grafted materials showed a gradual decrease in the pore size, BET surface area, and pore volume upon their stepwise functionalization. Although the functionalization reduced the total pore volume, the average pore sizes of the dendrimer-functionalized silica materials were still large enough (from 7.4 to 15.2 nm for PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and 2.3 nm for PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1) for easy diffusion of REE ions into the silica pores. The quantity of the organic moieties grafted on the silica materials was measured by TGA (Fig. 2), and the corresponding values are given in Table 1. For MSF-based materials, the weight losses of 10.3, 6.4, and 17.0% were measured respectively for NH2-MSF, GTA-NH2MSF, and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF after heating the samples to 800 °C, which corresponded to ca. 8.5, 6.4, and 17.1 wt% of APTES, GTA, and PAMAM grafted on the MSF; these values were estimated based on the differences in the weight losses before and after each functionalization step. Similarly, ca. 7.9, 4.9, and 13.2 wt% of the same functional groups were found grafted on the KCC-1 surface. Since the MSF had larger pore size as well as the higher pore volume and surface area than KCC-1, more PAMAM dendrimer was found functionalized on the surface. The grafting density of the PAMAM dendrimer on MSF and KCC-1was estimated to be ca. 0.038 and 0.033mg/m2 respectively based on the differences in N contents between NH2-MSF (or NH2-KCC-1) and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF (or PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1).
As shown in the SEM and TEM images in Fig. 3, the pristine MSF
sample (Fig. 3(a) and (c)) exhibits a hierarchical pore structure consisted of spherical voids with large meso- and macropores with sizes in the range of 15–30 nm interconnected by “windows.” These “treebranched” materials were reported to show significantly enhanced diffusion rates [29]. On the other hand, the SEM images of the KCC-1
(Fig. 4 (a) and (a1)) indicate the presence of dendrimeric fibers organized in three dimensions forming uniform spheres with an average size of 220 nm. As shown in the TEM images (Fig. 4(c) and (c1)), the KCC-1 nanospheres are composed of well-defined fibers which spread out from the center of the spherical particles and uniformly grown in all direction. After dendrimer immobilization on the pristine silica materials, reduced pore sizes were clearly visible with little changes to the surface roughness in the SEM and TEM images (Fig. 3(b) and (d) for PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and Fig. 4(b) and (d) for PAMAM@GTA-NH2KCC-1, respectively). No significant shrinkage of the pore channels in MSF was detected after functionalization with APTES and with GTAAPTES groups (Fig. S3), implying that the considerable shrinkage of the pore channels was mainly associated with the bulky G2 PAMAM dendrimer immobilized on the silica surface, which occupied a significant portion of the pore volume (Fig. 1(b)) [29]. It was also confirmed that the dendrimer was immobilized relatively uniformly onto the surface as supported by the TEM-EDX elemental distribution mapping (Figs. S4 and S5). Even after the incorporation of organic moieties, the functionalized materials largely maintained the hierarchically mesoporous and fibrous structures of MSF and KCC-1, which can facilitate the diffusion of REE ions and promote adsorption.
To monitor the changes in the surface chemical composition of the silica materials during the stepwise functionalization, FT-IR, XPS, and elemental analysis were conducted. FT-IR spectra of the pristine and functionalized silica materials were shown in Fig. 5. In all cases, the strong peaks at 805 and 1080 cm−1, relatively broad peaks at 945 cm−1, and peak at 3432 cm−1 were assignable to the Si-O-Si symmetric, asymmetric stretching modes, and Si-OH stretching

After APTES functionalization, NH2-MSF and NH2-KCC-1 showed the characteristic vibration at 2942 cm−1 corresponding to the –CH stretching from the CH2 groups of the alkyl chain [13] and the peak at 1486 cm−1 was assignable to the N–H bending vibration of primary amines. The diminished intensity of the broad peak corresponding to the hydroxyl group stretching vibration signaled covalent bonding of the surface silanols with APTES in NH2MSF and NH2-KCC-1. The FT-IR spectra of the dendrimer-functionalized silica materials further exhibited peaks at 1450, 1560, and 1650 cm−1
ascribed to amine (–NH2) and amide (–C]O–N) groups from the G2 PAMAM dendrimer moieties. These FT-IR spectral features agreed well with the previous reports [13,36,43]. As shown in Fig. S6 for XPS analysis, APTES-functionalized MSF and KCC-1 exhibited the N 1s binding energy peak at 399.6 eV, indicating the presence of primary amine group (–NH2) from APTES [13]. In addition, as shown in Fig. 6 (c
and f), new binding energy peaks at 399.6, 400.5, and 401.3 eV for primary, secondary, and tertiary amine groups, assignable to N 1 s from the dendrimer [13,44], appeared in both PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1. They also showed the XPS deconvoluted peaks of the C 1 s binding energies at 284.4, 285.4, and 287.0 eV, which were consistent with C–C, C–N, and N–C]O frequencies, respectively (Fig. 6 (b and e)) [33,45]. The N contents on their surface were estimated to be 4.58% and 3.98%, respectively, measured by EA and TEMEDS analyses (Figs. S4 and S5). These analyses all indicated that successful surface functionalization was carried out on both MSF and KCC1 silica materials.
To analyze the surface charge states of the dendrimer-functionalized silica materials, their zeta potential was measured in colloidal aqueous solutions at different pH, and the result is shown in Fig. 7. The isoelectric point of PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF (at around pH 4.8) was
higher than that of PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1 (at around pH 3.9), indicating that the former had a greater dendrimer functionalization than the latter [46]. The higher N content of the former obtained by EA analysis also supports this result (Table 1). At lower pH values (pH < 3), positive zeta potential values were obtained (+26.3 and 23.1 mV for PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1, respectively) because of the protonation of amine functionality on the dendrimer and hydroxyl groups on the surface of silica, which hampers the Gd3+ adsorption. At higher pH values (pH > 5), on the other hand, the surfaces of both materials showed high negative charges that increased with the solution pH due to deprotonation of the functional groups in the dendrimer and silica support. The zeta potential decreased to −18.8 and −11.2 mV for PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and
PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1, respectively, at pH 6. Considering the electrostatic interaction, the PAMAM dendrimer-functionalized silica materials can be expected to promote the adsorption of metal cations, e.g., REE ions, by allowing the ions to interact with the bulk of the deprotonated functional groups in the dendrimer at around this pH value. Therefore, pH ≈ 6 was selected for the following adsorption studies.

sections.heading: 3.2. REE ions adsorption by PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1
sections.text:
Initially, the adsorption performance of REEs (La3+, Ce3+, Nd3+, and Gd3+) on PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1 was examined using an initial concentration of 200 ppm for each metal ion at pH 6. The adsorption capacities followed the order of Gd3+ > Nd3+ > Ce3+ > La3+ for both materials as shown in Table 2. A similar trend was reported among these REE ions over other adsorbents [19,47]. This could be explained by the order of the ionic radii, La3+ (1.03 Å) > Ce3+ (1.02 Å) > Nd3+ (0.98 Å) > Gd3+
(0.93 Å) [48], as a smaller ionic radius leads to a higher uptake on the adsorption sites due to the steric hindrance effect [49]. PAMAM@GTANH2-MSF showed significantly higher adsorption capacities for all the REE ions tested in comparison with PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1, due to the relatively high density of dendrimer groups attached on its mesopore surface (see Table 1). Gd3+, the REE ion most readily adsorbed on
these materials, was chosen for further adsorption studies for the effect of pH, initial ion concentrations, and contact time, and selectivity against competing alkali/transition metal ions.
In order to verify the actual binding sites in the adsorbents for REE ions, the equilibrium adsorption measurements of the functionalized materials for Gd3+ were made after each functionalization step. As shown in Table S1, the adsorption capacities for Gd3+ increased in the sequence MSF (or KCC-1) < NH2-MSF (or NH2-KCC-1) < GTA-NH2MSF (or GTA-NH2-KCC-1) < PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF (or PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1). The pristine MSF and KCC-1 showed little adsorption, which increased somewhat after APTES grafting owing to binding of Gd3+ by the amines in APTES. Interestingly, after subsequent GTA functionalization on NH2-MSF and -KCC-1, considerable enhancement of Gd3+ adsorption took place. Gd3+ can interact with the carbonyl groups in GTA-NH2-MSF and -KCC-1, respectively, which exhibit Lewis basic characteristics for Gd3+ adsorption [20]. Free NH2 groups from the grafted APTES unreacted with the GTA could also contribute towards the adsorption to a small extent. The contribution of the carbonyl groups in GTA for Gd3+ adsorption, however, decreases after introducing G2 PAMAM dendrimer to GTA-NH2-MSF or GTA-NH2KCC-1, since their reaction with the amine groups in the dendrimer forms an imine cross-linker (see Scheme 1). The formed imine groups in PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF (or PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1 have little effectiveness for Gd3+ adsorption compared with the abundant amide groups in PAMAM because of the lower basicity of the imine group than amides [50]. The PAMAM dendrimer used in this study also has a large number of amine groups (Fig. S1), some acting as binding sites for Gd3+and some reacting with the carbonyl group in GTA. It is likely that several grafted GTA molecules are involved in the reaction with a single dendrimer species, and dendrimers will be more openly exposed to REE ions inside the pores of MSF or KCC-1 than GTA or APTES. Therefore, the adsorption capacities exhibited by PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF (or PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1) are most likely due to the immobilized dendrimers rather residual carbonyls or free amines. Gd3+ adsorption by PAMAM-immobilized silicas can be thus more complex than anticipated, which can include the adsorption by some unreacted functional groups in the prior functionalization step.
Zhang et al. [51] recently attempted to capture REE ions (La3+, Nd3+, and Sm3+) using a PAMAM dendrimer-functionalized crop waste, and reported low REE adsorption capacities (40.2, 30.6, and 22.0 mg/g for La3+, Nd3+, and Sm3+, respectively) accompanied by slow adsorption kinetics (4 h for equilibrium). Thus the judicious selection of support materials and improved functionalization scheme seem critical for efficient REE ions adsorption in water.

sections.heading: 3.3. pH effect on REE adsorption
sections.text:
Solution pH influences adsorption processes critically since it can control the overall surface charge of the adsorbents and ionization of the adsorbates [52]. The pH range examined here was restricted to 2–6, since Gd3+ could be precipitated as insoluble Gd(OH)3 in basic aqueous solutions (pH > 7) [53]. As shown in Fig. 8, the Gd3+ adsorption capacities of both PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC1 increased rapidly in the range of pH 4–6, from 38.2 to 130.5mg/g for the former and from 42.1 to 87.5 for the latter, similar to the reported results of mesoporous silica-based adsorbents for U(VI) and/or REE ions [10–14]. The highest adsorption capacity for Gd3+ over both materials was achieved at approximately pH 6. Since the adsorption proceeded via coordination interaction between Gd3+ and Lewis basic sites in the dendrimer, deprotonation of amine and amide groups in the dendrimerfunctionalized materials when the solution pH increased would enhance their binding abilities for adsorption. Gd3+ ions can also interact with the free –NH2 group (as mentioned above) having a lone pair of electrons via coordination bonding between the N atoms and Gd3+ ions, and –NH2–OH− sites formed on the surface of PAMAM@GTANH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1 via electrostatic attraction
between –NH2–OH- and Gd3+ ion at relatively higher pH [47]. Under the acidic pH environment, the amine groups are protonated to form positively charged sites of –NH3+ and –NH2+-, which electrostatically repel the Gd3+ ions [19,34]. Indeed, little adsorption proceeded below pH 3 because of the electrostatic repulsion [44]. This pH dependence is used for adsorbent regeneration, by adsorbing Ga3+ at pH≈ 6 and desorbing it at around pH 3.

sections.heading: 3.4. Adsorption sites and mechanism
sections.text:
To identify the interaction between the adsorption sites of PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1 and Gd3+ ion, FT-IR spectra of the adsorbents before and after Gd3+ adsorption were compared as shown in Fig. S7. After Gd3+ adsorption, the intensity of the characteristic peaks at 1450, 1560, and 1650 cm−1 assignable to amine (–NH2) and amide (–C]O–N) groups in the G2 PAMAM dendrimer decreased and became broad. Moreover, the absorption bands of the coordinated functional groups shifted slightly from 1560 to 1609 cm−1 for C]O of amide groups because of the interaction between the functional groups in the dendrimer and Gd3+ ions [45,54,55]. Additionally, the band around at 3300–3500 cm−1
ascribed to the N–H stretching vibration from free amine groups weakened significantly after adsorption of Gd3+ [6,20], suggesting that the amine groups also participated in the adsorption. These results were also similar to the cases of the dendrimer-functionalized silica materials for the removal of heavy metal ions such as Hg(II) [37] and Pb(II) [38].
Based on the characterization results of zeta potential measurements (Fig. 7), Gd3+ adsorption under varying pH conditions (Fig. 8), and FT-IR spectra of PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2KCC-1 before and after Gd3+ adsorption (Fig. S7), possible adsorption sites of the silica-based adsorbents for Gd3+ adsorption are described in Fig. 9.

The isotherm parameters calculated are given in Table 3. Both adsorbents exhibited typical Langmuir adsorption behavior that implies monolayer adsorption on homogeneous binding sites in agreement with the previous literature on mesoporous silica-based adsorbents [12–14]. The data fitted significantly better to the Langmuir model with a correlation factor R2> 0.99 (Table 3, Fig. 10 and Fig. S8). The equilibrium adsorption capacities (qm) of Gd3+ calculated using this model were 132.4 and 88.7mg/g for PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTANH2-KCC-1, respectively (Table 3), which matched quite well with the experimental values. Under the same conditions, the adsorption capacity of PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF was higher than that of PAMAM@GTANH2-KCC-1, because of its relatively large pore size and high density of functionalized dendrimer on the surface. The adsorption capacities of
Gd3+ on PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1 and other adsorbents reported previously are compared in Table 4. As shown, the value of PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF for Gd3+ in this work (132.4 mg/g) is one of the highest values reported so far.

sections.heading: 3.6. Adsorption kinetics
sections.text:
To examine the Gd3+ adsorption kinetics behavior over PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1, the adsorption was monitored for contact times of 0–4 h at the optimal pH of 6. As shown in Fig. 11, the adsorption equilibrium of Gd3+ on PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF was attained within only 20min, while that of PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1 took 45min at the same initial Gd3+ concentration. As the adsorption proceeds, the exterior surface of the individual adsorbent attains saturation first, and subsequently, the ions would diffuse into the pores to attain a final equilibrium state [58]. Most previous investigations reported that the time necessary for Gd3+
adsorption on different adsorbents ranges from 10min to 24 h (Table 4): less than 10min by 1-hydroxy-2-pyridinone-functionalized mesoporous silica [59] or phosphorous acid-functionalized mesoporous SBA-15 [60], 3 h by cesium molybdo vanado phosphate immobilized on SBA-15 [61], and 24 h by ZIFs [62]. The time required to reach equilibrium on PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF was short and close to that of the best mesoporous silica materials [12]. This relatively fast adsorption rate must have resulted by the enhanced diffusion of Gd3+ ions into the large mesopores of MSF, the surface of which is populated with abundant adsorption sites functionalized with dendrimer for Gd3+ (see Table 1).

sections.heading: 3.7. Selectivity tests
sections.text:
Selective adsorption toward the target metal ion in the presence of competitive ions is desired for practical application [65]. The effect of alkali/transition metal ions (Na+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Al3+, and Fe3+) on Gd3+ adsorption by PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2KCC-1 was examined at approximately pH 5.5 in a solution containing 50 ppm of each of the five ions. As shown in Fig. 12, the selectivity of PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1 toward Gd3+ was ca. 76% and 68%, respectively, while those of the other metal ions were less than 5% for bivalent Ca2+, Mg2+ and 20% for trivalent Al3+ and Fe3+. A similar trend was reported among other silica-based materials [19,66,67]. According to the HSAB (hard and soft acids and bases) theory, Gd3+ as a typical hard acid is expected to bind strongly than other competing trivalent ions with O and N donor atoms in the dendrimer [36]. The potential effect of the concentration of Al3+ and Fe3+ ions on the selectivity in Gd3+ solution from 0 to 100mmol/L in the pH range of 4–6 was further investigated, and the results are shown in Fig S10. Even under the conditions of high Al3+ or Fe3+ concentration (up to 100mM), PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF still showed a relatively high adsorption capacity of Gd3+ (0.83 mmol/g, 131mg/g) without precipitation of the competing cations [60]. The slight decrease in adsorption capacity of Gd3+ upon addition of increasingly high Al3+ or Fe3+ may be due to the increased coordination of Al3+ or Fe3+ to functional groups in PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF. While the selectivity of PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF is reasonable compared with other reported adsorbent materials [19,66], we managed to enhance it further by successive functionalization of PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF with PMIDA ligand by forming C–N bondings between the grafted NH2 moiety in PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and the PMIDA groups to obtain PMIDA/ PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF (Fig. S2). According to Fig. S11, P atoms from the PMIDA organic groups were found evenly distributed on the surface of PMIDA/PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF, indicating successful functionalization of PMIDA on the surface of PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF. As shown in Fig. 12, the selectivity to Gd3+ was further increased to 86% after the
functionalization, due to the enhanced Lewis basicity on the adsorption sites [20,34]. This highly selective adsorption towards Gd3+ is most likely owing to the synergistic effects from the different donor species, namely phosphonic-, carboxyl-, and carbonyl groups coexisting within the PMIDA [20].

sections.heading: 3.8. Adsorbent reusability
sections.text: To evaluate the reusability of the PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1, five consecutive adsorption/desorption runs were conducted. Since the desorption of Gd3+ ions is promoted by the decreases in solution pH due to the positive surface charge of the adsorbent as mentioned earlier, stripping of Gd3+ ions was performed using 0.1 mol/L HCl as a stripping agent. As shown in Fig. 13, both PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1 retained almost their initial adsorption efficiency during the recycles, implying that there was little deterioration of the functionalized groups on MSF and KCC-1 during the recycle runs. The stability of the functional groups in the materials after five recycles was confirmed by FT-IR (Fig. S12), showing no significant changes in the bonding between the dendrimer functional group and MSF and/or KCC-1 structure.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Second-generation G2 PAMAM dendrimer immobilized on a mesoporous silica foam (MSF) and on a fibrous nano-silica KCC-1 (PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1, respectively) were prepared, systematically characterized, and applied as adsorbents for the recovery of Gd3+ from aqueous solutions. Gd3+
adsorption equilibrium data on both materials were correlated excellently to the Langmuir model, and the maximum adsorption capacities were 132.4 and 88.7mg/g for PAMAM@GTA-NH2-MSF and PAMAM@GTA-NH2-KCC-1, respectively, at the optimum pH of 6.
